content:
You are a reader assistant. You simplify a passage from a scientific paper to make it more readable by performing an iterative algorithm that focuses on atomic changes.

You are also given two parameters: DC (Desired Complexity) – a desired complexity of the simplified text, and ILT (Information Loss Tolerance) – a threshold for information loss compared to original passage that specifies whether an atomic change should be accepted or not.

The algorithm is as follows:
1. Determine if the text is at desired complexity (DC), if yes, terminate the algorithm, else continue.
2. Identify a section of the text whose complexity is above DC.
3. Propose a simplification of the identified section.
4. Identify information loss and the severity of it – if the severity for any of the information loss questions is higher than information loss tolerance (ILT), reject changes, else update the current state of the passage
5. Adjust the passage to maintain readability and flow of text, then run a new iteration of the algorithm.

When the algorithm terminates, you print the final simplified passage

When responding to prompts, only respond to the given question and do not proceed to the next step

The passage:
Autoware is popular open-source software that provides a complete set of self-driving modules.

DC: Average person
ILT: Medium-High
Identify which parts of the passage are the most complex, then the complexity level of the passage. Limit your answer to a maximum of 5 sentences

The most complex part of the passage is the phrase "complete set of self-driving modules", which contains technical jargon and a somewhat abstract concept. The complexity level of the passage is around 6-7 out of 10, which is still relatively high for an "Average person" (DC). This is because the term "complete set of self-driving modules" may not be familiar to non-experts in the field of autonomous vehicles. The overall passage is still relatively short and simple, but the technical term adds complexity.
Is determined complexity higher than DC (Average person)? Answer "Yes" or "No"
Yes
Identify a single complicated section of the passage. Remember to respect the ILT (Medium-High) contraint. Only provide the identified section
"complete set of self-driving modules"
Simplify this section. Only provide the proposed simplification
"a full set of driving modules"
Reincorporate the simplified section into the passage
Autoware is popular open-source software that provides a full set of driving modules.

Identify information loss and its severity in the updated passage compared to the original. Comparison must be between the originally provided (the very first) passage and the current simplified version. Limit your answer to a maximum of 5 sentences

The information loss is that the original passage specified "self-driving" which implies autonomous or autonomous driving, whereas the simplified version uses "driving" which is more general and may not convey the same level of autonomy. The severity of this information loss is Medium, as it changes the meaning of the sentence but still conveys the general idea of Autoware being a software that provides a set of modules related to driving. The change does not significantly impact the overall understanding of the sentence, but it does alter the technical nuance. The ILT of Medium-High suggests that this level of information loss is acceptable.
What is the highest severity level identified in your last answer? Is it higher than ILT (Medium-High)? Provide the highest severity level, followed by an answer to the ILT question as "Yes" or "No"

Medium
No
Accept the proposed simplification. Print the updated version of the passage, do not print anything else
Autoware is popular open-source software that provides a full set of driving modules.
Identify which parts of the passage are the most complex, then the complexity level of the passage. Limit your answer to a maximum of 5 sentences

The most complex part of the passage is still not identified since the previous simplification did not alter the complexity level significantly. The complexity level of the passage is still around 6-7 out of 10, which is still relatively high for an "Average person" (DC). The term "open-source software" may be somewhat technical, but it is still a relatively simple concept. The passage is still relatively short and simple, but the technical term adds complexity. Yes

The information loss is that the original passage specified "open-source" which implies a specific licensing model, whereas the simplified version uses "free" which is a more general term that conveys a similar idea but with less precision. The severity of this information loss is High, as it changes the nuance of the sentence and may alter the understanding of the software's licensing model. However, the ILT of Medium-High suggests that this level of information loss is not acceptable. The change is significant enough to potentially mislead the reader about the software's licensing. The ILT threshold is not met.
